title: Causal Data Science
text:
This Site has my solutions for the Causal Data Science for Business Analytics course at the TUHH.


Have fun reading!

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
library(ggdag)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'ggdag'


#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter

library(ggplot2)

data<-readRDS("C:/Users/Marcel/Master/DataScience/data/membership.rds")
head(data)



  


dag<-dagify(avg_purch ~ card,
              card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch,
              pre_avg_purch ~ sex + age,
              exposure = "card",
              outcome = "avg_purch")


ggdag(dag)

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
3.1 1

library(MatchIt)
cem = matchit(card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch, data=data, method='cem', estimant='ATE')
df_cem<-match.data(cem)
lm_cem<-lm(avg_purch ~ card, data=df_cem, weights=weights)
summary(lm_cem)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -100.835  -23.724   -5.299   15.436  217.036 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  75.2842     0.3946   190.8   <2e-16 ***
#> card         15.1944     0.6078    25.0   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 29.83 on 9878 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0595, Adjusted R-squared:  0.05941 
#> F-statistic:   625 on 1 and 9878 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
3.2 2

nn<-matchit(card ~ age + pre_avg_purch , data=data, method="nearest", distance = "mahalanobis", replace = T )
df_nn<-match.data(nn)
model_nn<-lm(avg_purch ~ card, data=df_nn ,weights=weights)
summary(model_nn)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_nn, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -101.515  -21.159   -1.517   18.610  181.319 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  76.2067     0.5844  130.40   <2e-16 ***
#> card         14.9524     0.7479   19.99   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 30.37 on 6930 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.05453,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.05439 
#> F-statistic: 399.7 on 1 and 6930 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
3.3 3

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks ggdag::filter(), stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

model_prop<-glm(card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch, data=data, family = binomial(link = "logit"))
df_aug<-data %>% mutate(propensity = predict(model_prop, type = "response"))
df_ipw<-df_aug %>% mutate(ipw = (card/propensity) + ((1-card) / (1-propensity)))
model_ipw<-lm(avg_purch~card,data=df_ipw,weights=ipw)
summary(model_ipw)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_ipw, weights = ipw)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -205.353  -28.995   -0.275   28.787  214.307 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  70.2628     0.4320  162.66   <2e-16 ***
#> card         14.9573     0.6109   24.48   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 43.19 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.05657,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.05647 
#> F-statistic: 599.5 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
1 Assignment 1

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(dagitty)
#library(ggthemr) package ‘ggthemr’ is not available for this version of R
library(ggdag)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'ggdag'
#> 
#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter

dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="-3,-3,3,3"
Sales [outcome,pos="2.000,0.000"]
Store1 [pos="-2.000,2.000"]
Store2 [pos="-2.000,1.000"]
Store3 [pos="-2.000,-1.000"]
Store4 [pos="-2.000,-2.000"]
parkingspots [exposure,pos="0.000,0.000"]
Store1 -> parkingspots
Store2 -> parkingspots
Store3 -> parkingspots
Store4 -> parkingspots
parkingspots -> Sales
}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model);










2 Assignment 2

data <- readRDS("C:/Users/Marcel/Master/DataScience/data/customer_sat.rds")
print(data)

#> # A tibble: 15 × 3
#>    follow_ups satisfaction subscription
#>         <dbl>        <dbl> <chr>       
#>  1          8           40 Elite       
#>  2          7           45 Elite       
#>  3          8           47 Elite       
#>  4          9           44 Elite       
#>  5         10           50 Elite       
#>  6          6           55 Premium+    
#>  7          7           60 Premium+    
#>  8          6           62 Premium+    
#>  9          8           59 Premium+    
#> 10          8           65 Premium+    
#> 11          0           70 Premium     
#> 12          1           74 Premium     
#> 13          2           77 Premium     
#> 14          2           74 Premium     
#> 15          3           80 Premium

reg1 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
summary(reg1,digits = 2)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

reg2 <- lm(satisfaction ~ ., data = data)
summary(reg2,digits = 2)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ ., data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08




3 Assignment 3
The difference between the coefficients shows that the satisfaction due to follow ups is influenced by the subscription level of the clients.
Not accounting for the subscription level would indicate that the follow up calls decrease satisfaction level. Accounting for the subscription level shows that this is not the case. This could indicate that customers that pay for higher subscription levels expect follow up calls for the price they pay while some lower paying customers might find it more annoying.
Another important point is that we do not have a lot of data. The range of follow up calls is different for each type of subscription. While the Premium subscribers are on average the most satisfied according to this data they are also the ones called the least. The results might change if they get called as much as the other groups.


4 Assignment 4

#Satisfaction not conditioned on subscription level
sat_not_cond <- ggplot(data,aes(x = satisfaction, y = follow_ups))+
  geom_point()+
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F)

#Satisfaction conditioned on subscription level
sat_cond <- ggplot(data,aes(x = satisfaction, y = follow_ups, group=subscription, color=subscription))+
  geom_point()+
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F)

sat_not_cond

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








sat_cond

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
1 Assignment 1

car_prices <- readRDS("C:/Users/Marcel/Master/DataScience/data/car_prices.rds")
dim(car_prices)

#> [1] 181  22


The data has 22 rows and 181 columns.


2 Assignment 2

head(car_prices)



  



The data contains Strings <chr> and numbers <dbl>. Numbers can be compared and ordered by size and used for maths, while strings can mainly be checked for equality. (Or ordered by their characters)


3 Assignment 3

lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices)
summary(lm_all,digits = 2)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max

#> 
#> Coefficients:

#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172

#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .

#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***

#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***

#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545

#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***

#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035

#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761

#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom

#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

#confint(lm_all, level = 0.95)



4 Assignment 4
The peakrpm is a number that takes on values between 4200 and 6600 in our data.
Increasing the peakrpm by one would increase the price of the vehicle by $2.56.
This result is statistically significant as it has three stars in the summary table which correspond to a p-value between 0 and 0.001.


5 Assignment 5

library(tidyverse)
new <- car_prices %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE)
lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = new)
summary(lm_all,digits = 2)

The values of seat_heating are all NA the reason for this could be that as the value is the same for each entry the regression doe not know what would change if the seat_heating value would change.

title: Probability Theory
text:
1 Assignment 1
The probability of two consecutive events is obtained by multiplying the probabilities.
\(P(T \cap S) = 0.06\)
\(P(T \cap \overline{S})= 0.24\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap S) = 0.42\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) = 0.28\)
\(P(T \cap S) + P(T \cap \overline{S}) + P(\overline{T} \cap S)+P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S})=1\)

a<-0.3*0.2
b<-0.3*0.8

c<-0.7*0.6
d<-0.7*0.4

a

#> [1] 0.06

b

#> [1] 0.24

c

#> [1] 0.42

d

#> [1] 0.28

a+b+c+d

#> [1] 1




2 Assignment 2
Percentage of customers using all three devices: \(0.5\%\)
Percentage of customers using at least two devices: \(7.3\%+3.3\%+8.8\%+0.5\% = 19.9\%\)
Percentage of users using only one device: \(42\%+10\%+27.8\%=79.8\%\)

7.3+3.3+8.8+0.5 

#> [1] 19.9

42+10+27.8

#> [1] 79.8




3 Assignment 3
These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.8% that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.2% that the product is faulty.

ba<-0.97
bna<-0.01
a<-0.04

nab<-(bna*(1-a))/((bna*(1-a))+(ba*(a)))
nab

#> [1] 0.1983471

ab<-(ba*a)/((ba*a)+(bna*(1-a)))
ab

#> [1] 0.8016529

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
1 Assignment 1

random_vars <- readRDS("C:/Users/Marcel/Master/DataScience/data/random_vars.rds")
expected_age <- mean(random_vars$age)
cat("Age, Expected:",expected_age)

#> Age, Expected: 33.471

variance_age <- var(random_vars$age)
cat("Age, Variance:",variance_age)

#> Age, Variance: 340.6078

std_dev_age <- sd(random_vars$age)
cat("Age, Standard Deviation:",std_dev_age)

#> Age, Standard Deviation: 18.45556

expected_income <- mean(random_vars$income)
cat("Income, Expected:",expected_income)

#> Income, Expected: 3510.731

variance_income <- var(random_vars$income)
cat("Income, Variance:",variance_income)

#> Income, Variance: 8625646

std_dev_income <- sd(random_vars$income)
cat("Income, Standard Deviation:",std_dev_income)

#> Income, Standard Deviation: 2936.945




2 Assignment 2
It makes sense to compare the standard deviations of both variables. The low std dev for the age indicates that a lot of the given values are close to the expected value but the high standard deviation of the income shows that the difference of income varies far more than the age for the given date.


3 Assignment 3

covariance <- cov(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)
cat("Covariance:", covariance)

#> Covariance: 29700.15

correlation <- cor(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)
cat("Correlation:", correlation)

#> Correlation: 0.5479432




4 Assignment 4
I find the correlation easier to understand. A high covariance means that with increasing age the income also increases. I am not sure which values are “high”. As the values of correlation are bound between -1 and 1 its easier to understand which values are high enough to mean something.


5 Assignment 5

u18 <- random_vars[random_vars$age <= 18, ]
expected_income_u18 <- mean(u18$income)
cat("Income, Expected, u18:",expected_income_u18)

#> Income, Expected, u18: 389.6074

age18to65 <- random_vars[random_vars$age < 65, ]
age18to65 <- age18to65[age18to65$age >= 18, ]
expected_income_age18to65 <- mean(age18to65$income)
cat("Income, Expected, age18to65:",expected_income_age18to65)

#> Income, Expected, age18to65: 4685.734

o65 <- random_vars[random_vars$age >= 65, ]
expected_income_o65 <- mean(o65$income)
cat("Income, Expected, o65:",expected_income_o65)

#> Income, Expected, o65: 1777.237

title: Causality
text:
Source: https://tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations

library(ggplot2)
dates<-c(1999:2009)
cars_s<-c(758000,863000,837000,930000,830000,810000,923000,1154000,1183000,1142000,829000)
scale<- 8500
s<-c(87,103,91,112,104,108,113,137,131,129,104)*scale



cars<-data.frame(year = dates,cars_sold = cars_s,suicides = s)
ggplot(cars,aes(x = year))+
  geom_line(aes(y = cars_sold))+
  geom_line(aes(y = suicides), color = "red")+
  scale_y_continuous("Japanese cars sold",sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . / scale,name="Suicides using car"))+
  theme(axis.title.y.right = element_text(color = "red"))+
  ggtitle("Correlation: Suicides using cars and Japanese car sales in the US")

title: Causality
text:
Source: https://tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations

library(ggplot2)
dates<-c(1999:2009)
cars_s<-c(758000,863000,837000,930000,830000,810000,923000,1154000,1183000,1142000,829000)
scale<- 8500
s<-c(87,103,91,112,104,108,113,137,131,129,104)*scale



cars<-data.frame(year = dates,cars_sold = cars_s,suicides = s)
ggplot(cars,aes(x = year))+
  geom_line(aes(y = cars_sold))+
  geom_line(aes(y = suicides), color = "red")+
  scale_y_continuous("Japanese cars sold",sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . / scale,name="Suicides using car"))+
  theme(axis.title.y.right = element_text(color = "red"))+
  ggtitle("Correlation: Suicides using cars and Japanese car sales in the US")

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
1 Assignment 1

library(ggplot2)
data <- readRDS("C:/Users/Marcel/Master/DataScience/data/abtest_online.rds")
head(data)



  


#View(data)

ggplot(data, aes(x = chatbot, y = previous_visit)) +
  stat_summary() +
  labs(title = "Balance",
       x = "Treatment Group",
       y = "Previous Visits")

#> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()`








data$mobile_device <- as.numeric(data$mobile_device)
#https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30943167/replace-logical-values-true-false-with-numeric-1-0
ggplot(data, aes(x = chatbot, y = mobile_device)) +
  stat_summary() +
  labs(title = "Balance",
       x = "Treatment Group",
       y = "Mobile Device")

#> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()`








ggplot(data, aes(x = chatbot, y = purchase)) +
  stat_summary() +
  labs(title = "Balance",
       x = "Treatment Group",
       y = "Purchase")

#> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()`








ggplot(data, aes(x = chatbot, y = purchase_amount)) +
  stat_summary() +
  labs(title = "Balance",
       x = "Treatment Group",
       y = "Purchase Amount")

#> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()`









The covariates are significantly unbalanced between both groups. While the mobile-device usage is quite similliar all other covariates are different.


2 Assignment 2

#Assuming it makes no difference if using True/False or 1/0

lm_sales <- lm(purchase~chatbot, data=data)
summary(lm_sales)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -0.4960 -0.3249 -0.2679  0.5040  0.7321 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  0.49597    0.02122  23.376  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE -0.22811    0.02989  -7.633 5.36e-14 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 0.4725 on 998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.05516,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.05421 
#> F-statistic: 58.26 on 1 and 998 DF,  p-value: 5.36e-14

lm_spent <- lm(purchase_amount~chatbot, data=data)
summary(lm_spent)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -16.702 -14.478  -9.626  13.922  64.648 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  16.7017     0.8374  19.944  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE  -7.0756     1.1796  -5.998 2.79e-09 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.65 on 998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0348, Adjusted R-squared:  0.03383 
#> F-statistic: 35.98 on 1 and 998 DF,  p-value: 2.787e-09


The chatbot decreases the number of sales and the amount spent during each transaction. As the groups are not really comparable due to their unbalanced covariates this result could be wrong.


3 Assignment 3

lm_cate <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device, data = data)
summary(lm_cate)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#> -16.98 -14.54  -9.95  14.13  65.24 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                           Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)                16.9797     1.0152  16.725   <2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE                -7.0301     1.4284  -4.922    1e-06 ***
#> mobile_device              -0.8727     1.7987  -0.485    0.628    
#> chatbotTRUE:mobile_device  -0.1526     2.5369  -0.060    0.952    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.66 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.03534,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03244 
#> F-statistic: 12.16 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 8.034e-08


While the chatbot itself decreases the purchase_amount by a big number, it only decreases the purchase amount by a small number if used on a mobile device. But the p value is too big.


4 Assignment 4

logistic_model <- glm(purchase ~ chatbot, data = data, family = binomial(link = 'logit'))
summary(logistic_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot, family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
#>     data = data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept) -0.01613    0.08981  -0.180    0.857    
#> chatbotTRUE -0.98939    0.13484  -7.337 2.18e-13 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 1329.1  on 999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 1273.3  on 998  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 1277.3
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4


Having the chatbot decreases the log odds by 0.989 compared to the users not using the chatbot.

title: Difference-in-Differences
text:
library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

data<-readRDS("C:/Users/Marcel/Master/DataScience/data/hospdd.rds")
head(data)



  


treatment_start<-data %>% filter(procedure == 1, hospital>=0, hospital<=18) %>% pull(month) %>% min()
treatment_start

#> [1] 4

treated_before<-data %>% filter(procedure == 0, hospital>=0, hospital<=18) %>% pull(satis) %>% mean()
treated_before

#> [1] 3.525383

treated_after<-data %>% filter(procedure == 1, hospital>=0, hospital<=18) %>% pull(satis) %>% mean()
treated_after

#> [1] 4.363351

control_before<-data %>% filter(month < 4, hospital>18) %>% pull(satis) %>% mean()
control_before

#> [1] 3.392509

control_after<-data %>% filter(month >= 4, hospital>18) %>% pull(satis) %>% mean()
control_after

#> [1] 3.38249

title: Difference-in-Differences
text:
2.1 1

linear<-lm(satis ~ month + hospital, data = data)
summary(linear)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satis ~ month + hospital, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -3.3831 -0.6724 -0.0838  0.5778  5.7881 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  3.7597212  0.0308145  122.01   <2e-16 ***
#> month        0.0720728  0.0055957   12.88   <2e-16 ***
#> hospital    -0.0175982  0.0008732  -20.16   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 1.017 on 7365 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.07208,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.07183 
#> F-statistic: 286.1 on 2 and 7365 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
